question_pool.question: On which HF/MF bands is a General class license holder granted all amateur frequency privileges?

answers.B: 160 meters, 80 meters, 40 meters, and 10 meters
answers.C: 160 meters, 60 meters, 30 meters, 17 meters, 12 meters, and 10 meters
answers.D: 160 meters, 30 meters, 17 meters, 15 meters, 12 meters, and 10 meters

question_pool.question: On which of the following bands is phone operation prohibited?

answers.B: 30 meters
answers.C: 17 meters

question_pool.question: On which of the following bands is image transmission prohibited?

answers.B: 30 meters
answers.C: 20 meters

question_pool.question: Which of the following amateur bands is restricted to communication only on specific channels, rather than frequency ranges?

answers.B: 12 meters
answers.C: 30 meters

question_pool.question: Which of the following frequencies is in the General class portion of the 40-meter band in ITU Region 2?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 75-meter phone band?

answers.B: 3750 kHz
answers.C: 3900 kHz

question_pool.question: Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 20-meter phone band?
Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 80-meter band?

answers.B: 2560 kHz
answers.C: 3560 kHz

question_pool.question: Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 15-meter band?
Which of the following frequencies is available to a control operator holding a General class license?
When General class licensees are not permitted to use the entire voice portion of a band, which portion of the voice segment is generally available to them?

answers.B: The upper frequency end
answers.C: The lower frequency end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz, and the upper end on frequencies above 14.150 MHz
answers.D: The upper frequency end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz, and the lower end on frequencies above 14.150 MHz

question_pool.question: Which of the following applies when the FCC rules designate the Amateur Service as a secondary user on a band?

answers.A: Amateur stations must record the call sign of the primary service station before operating on a frequency assigned to that station
answers.B: Amateur stations can use the band only during emergencies
answers.C: Amateur stations can use the band only if they do not cause harmful interference to primary users
answers.D: Amateur stations may only operate during specific hours of the day, while primary users are permitted 24- hour use of the band

question_pool.question: What is the appropriate action if, when operating on either the 30-meter or 60-meter bands, a station in the primary service interferes with your contact?

answers.A: Notify the FCCs regional Engineer in Charge of the interference
answers.B: Increase your transmitter’s power to overcome the interference
answers.C: Attempt to contact the station and request that it stop the interference
answers.D: Move to a clear frequency or stop transmitting

question_pool.question: Which of the following may apply in areas under FCC jurisdiction outside of ITU Region 2?

answers.A: Station identification may have to be in a language other than English
answers.B: Morse code may not be permitted
answers.C: Digital transmission may not be permitted

question_pool.question: What portion of the 10-meter band is available for repeater use?

answers.B: The portion between 28.1 MHz and 28.2 MHz
answers.C: The portion between 28.3 MHz and 28.5 MHz

question_pool.question: What is the maximum height above ground to which an antenna structure may be erected without requiring notification to the FAA and registration with the FCC, provided it is not at or near a public use airport?

answers.B: 100 feet
answers.C: 200 feet

question_pool.question: With which of the following conditions must beacon stations comply?

answers.A: A beacon station may not use automatic control
answers.B: The frequency must be coordinated with the National Beacon Organization
answers.C: The frequency must be posted on the internet or published in a national periodical
answers.D: There must be no more than one beacon signal transmitting in the same band from the same station location

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a purpose of a beacon station as identified in the FCC rules?

answers.B: Automatic identification of repeaters
answers.C: Transmission of bulletins of general interest to Amateur Radio licensees

question_pool.question: Which of the following transmissions is permitted?

answers.A: Unidentified transmissions for test purposes only
answers.B: Retransmission of other amateur station signals by any amateur station
answers.C: Occasional retransmission of weather and propagation forecast information from U.S. government stations
answers.D: Coded messages of any kind, if not intended to facilitate a criminal act

question_pool.question: Which of the following one-way transmissions are permitted?

answers.A: Unidentified test transmissions of less than one minute in duration
answers.B: Transmissions necessary to assist learning the International Morse code
answers.C: Regular transmissions offering equipment for sale, if intended for Amateur Radio use

question_pool.question: Under what conditions are state and local governments permitted to regulate Amateur Radio antenna structures?

answers.A: Under no circumstances, FCC rules take priority
answers.B: At any time and to any extent necessary to accomplish a legitimate purpose of the state or local entity, provided that proper filings are made with the FCC
answers.C: Only when such structures exceed 50 feet in height and are clearly visible 1000 feet from the structure
answers.D: Amateur Service communications must be reasonably accommodated, and regulations must constitute the minimum practical to accommodate a legitimate purpose of the state or local entity

question_pool.question: What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the Amateur Service?

answers.B: They may be used if they do not obscure the meaning of a message
answers.C: They are not permitted

question_pool.question: When choosing a transmitting frequency, what should you do to comply with good amateur practice?

answers.A: Ensure that the frequency and mode selected are within your license class privileges
answers.B: Follow generally accepted band plans agreed to by the Amateur Radio community
answers.C: Monitor the frequency before transmitting

question_pool.question: On what HF frequencies are automatically controlled beacons permitted?

answers.A: On any frequency if power is less than 1 watt
answers.B: On any frequency if transmissions are in Morse code
answers.C: 21.08 MHz to 21.09 MHz

question_pool.question: What is the power limit for beacon stations?

answers.B: 20 watts PEP output
answers.C: 100 watts PEP output

question_pool.question: Who or what determines “good engineering and good amateur practice,” as applied to the operation of an amateur station in all respects not covered by the Part 97 rules?

answers.B: The control operator
answers.C: The IEEE

question_pool.question: When is it permissible to communicate with amateur stations in countries outside the areas administered by the Federal Communications Commission?

answers.A: Only when the foreign country has a formal third-party agreement filed with the FCC
answers.B: When the contact is with amateurs in any country except those whose administrations have notified the ITU that they object to such communications
answers.C: When the contact is with amateurs in any country as long as the communication is conducted in English
answers.D: Only when the foreign country is a member of the International Amateur Radio Union

question_pool.question: What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on 10.140 MHz?

answers.B: 1000 watts PEP output
answers.C: 1500 watts PEP output

question_pool.question: What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on the 12-meter band?

answers.B: 200 watts PEP output
answers.C: 1500 watts PEP output
answers.D: An effective radiated power equivalent to 100 watts from a half-wave dipole

question_pool.question: What is the maximum bandwidth permitted by FCC rules for Amateur Radio stations transmitting on USB frequencies in the 60-meter band?

answers.B: 5.6 kHz
answers.C: 1.8 kHz

question_pool.question: Which of the following limitations apply to transmitter power on every amateur band?

answers.A: Only the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communications should be used
answers.B: Power must be limited to 200 watts when using data transmissions
answers.C: Power should be limited as necessary to avoid interference to another radio service on the frequency
answers.D: Effective radiated power cannot exceed 1500 watts

question_pool.question: What is the limit for transmitter power on the 28 MHz band for a General Class control operator?

answers.B: 1000 watts PEP output
answers.C: 1500 watts PEP output

question_pool.question: What is the limit for transmitter power on the 1.8 MHz band?

answers.B: 1000 watts PEP output
answers.C: 1200 watts PEP output

question_pool.question: What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmission on the 20-meter band?

answers.B: 19.6 kilobaud
answers.C: 1200 baud

question_pool.question: What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmitted at frequencies below 28 MHz?

answers.B: 19.6 kilobaud
answers.C: 1200 baud

question_pool.question: What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmitted on the 1.25-meter and 70- centimeter bands?

answers.B: 19.6 kilobaud
answers.C: 1200 baud

question_pool.question: What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 10-meter band?

answers.B: 19.6 kilobaud
answers.C: 1200 baud

question_pool.question: What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 2-meter band?

answers.B: 19.6 kilobaud
answers.C: 1200 baud

question_pool.question: Which of the following is required by the FCC rules when operating in the 60-meter band?

answers.A: If you are using an antenna other than a dipole, you must keep a record of the gain of your antenna
answers.B: You must keep a record of the date, time, frequency, power level, and stations worked
answers.C: You must keep a record of all third-party traffic
answers.D: You must keep a record of the manufacturer of your equipment and the antenna used

question_pool.question: What must be done before using a new digital protocol on the air?

answers.B: Obtain an experimental license from the FCC
answers.C: Publicly document the technical characteristics of the protocol
answers.D: Submit a rule-making proposal to the FCC describing the codes and methods of the technique

question_pool.question: What is the maximum power limit on the 60-meter band?

answers.B: 10 watts RMS
answers.C: ERP of 100 watts PEP with respect to a dipole
answers.D: ERP of 100 watts PEP with respect to an isotropic antenna

question_pool.question: What measurement is specified by FCC rules that regulate maximum power output?

answers.B: Average
answers.C: Forward

question_pool.question: Who may receive partial credit for the elements represented by an expired Amateur Radio license?

answers.A: Any person who can demonstrate that they once held an FCC-issued General, Advanced, or Amateur Extra class license that was not revoked by the FCC
answers.B: Anyone who held an FCC-issued Amateur Radio license that has been expired for not less than 5 years and not more than 15 years
answers.C: Any person who previously held an amateur license issued by another country, but only if that country has a current reciprocal licensing agreement with the FCC
answers.D: Only persons who once held an FCC issued Novice, Technician, or Technician Plus license

question_pool.question: What license examinations may you administer when you are an accredited VE holding a General class operator license?

answers.B: General only
answers.C: Technician only

question_pool.question: On which of the following band segments may you operate if you are a Technician class operator and have a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class privileges?

answers.A: Only the Technician band segments until your upgrade is posted in the FCC database
answers.B: Only on the Technician band segments until your license arrives in the mail
answers.C: On any General or Technician class band segment
answers.D: On any General or Technician class band segment except 30 meters and 60 meters

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a requirement for administering a Technician class license examination?

answers.A: At least three General class or higher VEs must observe the examination
answers.B: At least two General class or higher VEs must be present
answers.C: At least two General class or higher VEs must be present, but only one need be Amateur Extra class
answers.D: At least three VEs of Technician class or higher must observe the examination

question_pool.question: Which of the following must a person have before they can be an administering VE for a Technician class license examination?

answers.A: Notification to the FCC that you want to give an examination
answers.B: Receipt of a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class
answers.C: Possession of a properly obtained telegraphy license
answers.D: An FCC General class or higher license and VEC accreditation

question_pool.question: When must you add the special identifier "AG" after your call sign if you are a Technician class licensee and have a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for General class operator privileges, but the FCC has not yet posted your upgrade on its website?

answers.A: Whenever you operate using General class frequency privileges
answers.B: Whenever you operate on any amateur frequency
answers.C: Whenever you operate using Technician frequency privileges
answers.D: A special identifier is not required if your General class license application has been filed with the FCC

question_pool.question: Volunteer Examiners are accredited by what organization?

answers.B: The Universal Licensing System
answers.C: A Volunteer Examiner Coordinator

question_pool.question: Which of the following criteria must be met for a non-U.S. citizen to be an accredited Volunteer Examiner?

answers.A: The person must be a resident of the U.S. for a minimum of 5 years
answers.B: The person must hold an FCC granted Amateur Radio license of General class or above
answers.C: The person’s home citizenship must be in ITU region 2
answers.D: None of these choices is correct; a non-U.S. citizen cannot be a Volunteer Examiner

question_pool.question: How long is a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) valid for exam element credit?

answers.B: 180 days
answers.C: 365 days
answers.D: For as long as your current license is valid

question_pool.question: What is the minimum age that one must be to qualify as an accredited Volunteer Examiner?

answers.B: 18 years
answers.C: 21 years

question_pool.question: What is required to obtain a new General Class license after a previously-held license has expired and the two- year grace period has passed?

answers.A: They must have a letter from the FCC showing they once held an amateur or commercial license
answers.B: There are no requirements other than being able to show a copy of the expired license
answers.C: The applicant must be able to produce a copy of a page from a call book published in the U.S. showing his or her name and address
answers.D: The applicant must pass the current Element 2 exam

question_pool.question: Which of the following would disqualify a third party from participating in stating a message over an amateur station?

answers.A: The third party’s amateur license has been revoked and not reinstated
answers.B: The third party is not a U.S. citizen
answers.C: The third party is a licensed amateur
answers.D: The third party is speaking in a language other than English

question_pool.question: When may a 10-meter repeater retransmit the 2-meter signal from a station that has a Technician class control operator?

answers.B: Only if the station on 10-meters is operating under a Special Temporary Authorization allowing such retransmission
answers.C: Only during an FCC-declared general state of communications emergency
answers.D: Only if the 10-meter repeater control operator holds at least a General class license

question_pool.question: What is required to conduct communications with a digital station operating under automatic control outside the automatic control band segments?

answers.A: The station initiating the contact must be under local or remote control
answers.B: The interrogating transmission must be made by another automatically controlled station
answers.C: No third-party traffic may be transmitted
answers.D: The control operator of the interrogating station must hold an Amateur Extra Class license

question_pool.question: Which of the following conditions require a licensed Amateur Radio operator to take specific steps to avoid harmful interference to other users or facilities?

answers.A: When operating within one mile of an FCC Monitoring Station
answers.B: When using a band where the Amateur Service is secondary
answers.C: When a station is transmitting spread spectrum emissions

question_pool.question: What types of messages for a third party in another country may be transmitted by an amateur station?

answers.A: Any message, as long as the amateur operator is not paid
answers.B: Only messages for other licensed amateurs
answers.C: Only messages relating to Amateur Radio or remarks of a personal character, or messages relating to emergencies or disaster relief
answers.D: Any messages, as long as the text of the message is recorded in the station log

question_pool.question: The frequency allocations of which ITU region apply to radio amateurs operating in North and South America?

answers.B: Region 3
answers.C: Region 2

question_pool.question: In what part of the 13-centimeter band may an amateur station communicate with non-licensed Wi-Fi stations?

answers.B: Channels 1 through 4
answers.C: Channels 42 through 45

question_pool.question: What is the maximum PEP output allowed for spread spectrum transmissions?

answers.B: 10 watts
answers.C: 100 watts

question_pool.question: Under what circumstances are messages that are sent via digital modes exempt from Part 97 third-party rules that apply to other modes of communication?

answers.B: When messages are encrypted
answers.C: When messages are not encrypted

question_pool.question: Why should an amateur operator normally avoid transmitting on 14.100, 18.110, 21.150, 24. 930 and 28.200 MHz?

answers.A: A system of propagation beacon stations operates on those frequencies
answers.B: A system of automatic digital stations operates on those frequencies
answers.C: These frequencies are set aside for emergency operations
answers.D: These frequencies are set aside for bulletins from the FCC

question_pool.question: On what bands may automatically controlled stations transmitting RTTY or data emissions communicate with other automatically controlled digital station?

answers.A: On any band segment where digital operation is permitted
answers.B: Anywhere in the non-phone segments of the 10-meter or shorter wavelength bands
answers.C: Only in the non-phone Extra Class segments of the bands
answers.D: Anywhere in the 6-meter or shorter wavelength bands, and in limited segments of some of the HF bands

question_pool.question: Which sideband is most commonly used for voice communications on frequencies of 14 MHz or higher?

answers.B: Lower sideband
answers.C: Vestigial sideband

question_pool.question: Which of the following modes is most commonly used for voice communications on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter bands?

answers.B: Lower sideband
answers.C: Vestigial sideband

question_pool.question: Which of the following is most commonly used for SSB voice communications in the VHF and UHF bands?

answers.B: Lower sideband
answers.C: Vestigial sideband

question_pool.question: Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on the 17-meter and 12-meter bands?

answers.B: Lower sideband
answers.C: Vestigial sideband

question_pool.question: Which mode of voice communication is most commonly used on the HF amateur bands?

answers.B: Double sideband
answers.C: Single sideband

question_pool.question: Which of the following is an advantage when using single sideband, as compared to other analog voice modes on the HF amateur bands?

answers.B: Less subject to interference from atmospheric static crashes
answers.C: Ease of tuning on receive and immunity to impulse noise
answers.D: Less bandwidth used and greater power efficiency

question_pool.question: Which of the following statements is true of the single sideband voice mode?

answers.A: Only one sideband and the carrier are transmitted; the other sideband is suppressed
answers.B: Only one sideband is transmitted; the other sideband and carrier are suppressed
answers.C: SSB is the only voice mode that is authorized on the 20-meter, 15-meter, and 10-meter amateur bands
answers.D: SSB is the only voice mode that is authorized on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter amateur bands

question_pool.question: What is the recommended way to break in to a phone contact?

answers.A: Say “QRZ” several times, followed by your call sign
answers.B: Say your call sign once
answers.C: Say “Breaker Breaker”
answers.D: Say “CQ” followed by the call sign of either station

question_pool.question: Why do most amateur stations use lower sideband on the 160-meter, 75-meter, and 40-meter bands?

answers.A: Lower sideband is more efficient than upper sideband at these frequencies
answers.B: Lower sideband is the only sideband legal on these frequency bands
answers.C: Because it is fully compatible with an AM detector

question_pool.question: Which of the following statements is true of voice VOX operation versus PTT operation?

answers.A: The received signal is more natural sounding
answers.B: It allows “hands free” operation
answers.C: It occupies less bandwidth

question_pool.question: Generally, who should respond to a station in the contiguous 48 states who calls “CQ DX”?

answers.A: Any caller is welcome to respond
answers.B: Only stations in Germany
answers.C: Any stations outside the lower 48 states

question_pool.question: What control is typically adjusted for proper ALC setting on an amateur single sideband transceiver?

answers.B: Transmit audio or microphone gain
answers.C: Antenna inductance or capacitance

question_pool.question: Which of the following is true concerning access to frequencies?

answers.B: QSOs in progress always have priority
answers.C: Except during emergencies, no amateur station has priority access to any frequency
answers.D: Contest operations must always yield to non-contest use of frequencies

question_pool.question: What is the first thing you should do if you are communicating with another amateur station and hear a station in distress break in?

answers.A: Continue your communication because you were on the frequency first
answers.B: Acknowledge the station in distress and determine what assistance may be needed
answers.C: Change to a different frequency

question_pool.question: What is good amateur practice if propagation changes during a contact and you notice interference from other stations on the frequency?

answers.A: Tell the interfering stations to change frequency
answers.B: Report the interference to your local Amateur Auxiliary Coordinator
answers.C: Attempt to resolve the interference problem with the other stations in a mutually acceptable manner

question_pool.question: When selecting a CW transmitting frequency, what minimum separation should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?

answers.B: 150 to 500 Hz
answers.C: 1 to 3 kHz

question_pool.question: When selecting an SSB transmitting frequency, what minimum separation should be used to minimize interference to stations on adjacent frequencies?

answers.B: 150 to 500 Hz
answers.C: Approximately 3 kHz

question_pool.question: What is a practical way to avoid harmful interference on an apparently clear frequency before calling CQ on CW or phone?

answers.A: Send “QRL?” on CW, followed by your call sign; or, if using phone, ask if the frequency is in use, followed by your call sign
answers.B: Listen for 2 minutes before calling CQ
answers.C: Send the letter “V” in Morse code several times and listen for a response, or say “test” several times and listen for a response
answers.D: Send “QSY” on CW or if using phone, announce “the frequency is in use,” then give your call sign and listen for a response

question_pool.question: Which of the following complies with good amateur practice when choosing a frequency on which to initiate a call?

answers.A: Check to see if the channel is assigned to another station
answers.B: Identify your station by transmitting your call sign at least 3 times
answers.C: Follow the voluntary band plan for the operating mode you intend to use

question_pool.question: What is the voluntary band plan restriction for U.S. stations transmitting within the 48 contiguous states in the 50.1 to 50.125 MHz band segment?

answers.A: Only contacts with stations not within the 48 contiguous states
answers.B: Only contacts with other stations within the 48 contiguous states
answers.C: Only digital contacts

question_pool.question: Who may be the control operator of an amateur station transmitting in RACES to assist relief operations during a disaster?

answers.A: Only a person holding an FCC-issued amateur operator license
answers.B: Only a RACES net control operator
answers.C: A person holding an FCC-issued amateur operator license or an appropriate government official
answers.D: Any control operator when normal communication systems are operational

question_pool.question: When is an amateur station allowed to use any means at its disposal to assist another station in distress?

answers.B: At any time when transmitting in an organized net
answers.C: At any time during an actual emergency

question_pool.question: What frequency should be used to send a distress call?

answers.A: Whichever frequency has the best chance of communicating the distress message
answers.B: Only frequencies authorized for RACES or ARES stations
answers.C: Only frequencies that are within your operating privileges
answers.D: Only frequencies used by police, fire, or emergency medical services

question_pool.question: Which of the following describes full break-in telegraphy (QSK)?

answers.A: Breaking stations send the Morse code prosign “BK”
answers.B: Automatic keyers, instead of hand keys, are used to send Morse code
answers.C: An operator must activate a manual send/receive switch before and after every transmission
answers.D: Transmitting stations can receive between code characters and elements

question_pool.question: What should you do if a CW station sends “QRS?”

answers.B: Change frequency
answers.C: Increase your power

question_pool.question: What does it mean when a CW operator sends “KN” at the end of a transmission?

answers.B: Operating full break-in
answers.C: Listening only for a specific station or stations

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QRL?” mean?

answers.B: “Are you operating full break-in?” or “Can you operate full break-in?”
answers.C: “Are you listening only for a specific station?”
answers.D: “Are you busy?” or “Is this frequency in use?”

question_pool.question: What is the best speed to use when answering a CQ in Morse code?

answers.A: The fastest speed at which you are comfortable copying, but no slower than the CQ
answers.B: The fastest speed at which you are comfortable copying, but no faster than the CQ
answers.C: At the standard calling speed of 10 wpm
answers.D: At the standard calling speed of 5 wpm

question_pool.question: What does the term “zero beat” mean in CW operation?

answers.A: Matching the speed of the transmitting station
answers.B: Operating split to avoid interference on frequency
answers.C: Sending without error
answers.D: Matching the transmit frequency to the frequency of a received signal

question_pool.question: When sending CW, what does a “C” mean when added to the RST report?

answers.B: Report was read from an S meter rather than estimated
answers.C: 100 percent copy

question_pool.question: What prosign is sent to indicate the end of a formal message when using CW?

answers.B: BK
answers.C: AR

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QSL” mean?

answers.B: We have already confirmed by card
answers.C: I acknowledge receipt

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QRN” mean?

answers.B: Stop sending
answers.C: Zero beat my signal

question_pool.question: What does the Q signal “QRV” mean?

answers.B: There is interference on the frequency
answers.C: I am quitting for the day
answers.D: I am ready to receive messages

question_pool.question: What is the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.A: Amateur volunteers who are formally enlisted to monitor the airwaves for rules violations
answers.B: Amateur volunteers who conduct amateur licensing examinations
answers.C: Amateur volunteers who conduct frequency coordination for amateur VHF repeaters
answers.D: Amateur volunteers who use their station equipment to help civil defense organizations in times of emergency

question_pool.question: Which of the following are objectives of the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.A: To conduct efficient and orderly amateur licensing examinations
answers.B: To encourage amateur radio operators to self-regulate and comply with the rules
answers.C: To coordinate repeaters for efficient and orderly spectrum usage
answers.D: To provide emergency and public safety communications

question_pool.question: What skills learned during hidden transmitter hunts are of help to the Volunteer Monitoring Program?

answers.B: Direction finding used to locate stations violating FCC rules
answers.C: Identification of different call signs
answers.D: Hunters have an opportunity to transmit on non-amateur frequencies

question_pool.question: Which of the following describes an azimuthal projection map?

answers.A: A map that shows accurate land masses
answers.B: A map that shows true bearings and distances from a particular location
answers.C: A map that shows the angle at which an amateur satellite crosses the equator
answers.D: A map that shows the number of degrees longitude that an amateur satellite appears to move westward at the equator with each orbit

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a good way to indicate on a clear frequency in the HF phone bands that you are looking for a contact with any station?

answers.A: Sign your call sign once, followed by the words “listening for a call” -- if no answer, change frequency and repeat
answers.B: Say “QTC” followed by “this is” and your call sign -- if no answer, change frequency and repeat
answers.C: Repeat “CQ” a few times, followed by “this is,” then your call sign a few times, then pause to listen, repeat as necessary
answers.D: Transmit an unmodulated carried for approximately 10 seconds, followed by “this is” and your call sign, and pause to listen -- repeat as necessary

question_pool.question: How is a directional antenna pointed when making a “long-path” contact with another station?

answers.B: Along the grayline
answers.C: 180 degrees from the station’s short-path heading

question_pool.question: Which of the following are examples of the NATO Phonetic Alphabet?

answers.B: Adam, Boy, Charles, David
answers.C: America, Boston, Canada, Denmark

question_pool.question: What is a reason why many amateurs keep a station log?

answers.A: The ITU requires a log of all international contacts
answers.B: The ITU requires a log of all international third-party traffic
answers.C: The log provides evidence of operation needed to renew a license without retest
answers.D: To help with a reply if the FCC requests information

question_pool.question: Which of the following is required when participating in a contest on HF frequencies?

answers.A: Submit a log to the contest sponsor
answers.B: Send a QSL card to the stations worked, or QSL via Logbook of The World
answers.C: Identify your station per normal FCC regulations

question_pool.question: What is QRP operation?

answers.B: Low-power transmit operation
answers.C: Transmission using Quick Response Protocol

question_pool.question: Which of the following is typical of the lower HF frequencies during the summer?

answers.A: Poor propagation at any time of day
answers.B: World-wide propagation during the daylight hours
answers.C: Heavy distortion on signals due to photon absorption
answers.D: High levels of atmospheric noise or “static”

question_pool.question: Which mode is normally used when sending RTTY signals via AFSK with an SSB transmitter?

answers.B: DSB
answers.C: CW

question_pool.question: How can a PACTOR modem or controller be used to determine if the channel is in use by other PACTOR stations?

answers.A: Unplug the data connector temporarily and see if the channel-busy indication is turned off
answers.B: Put the modem or controller in a mode which allows monitoring communications without a connection
answers.C: Transmit UI packets several times and wait to see if there is a response from another PACTOR station
answers.D: Send the message, ”Is this frequency in use?”

question_pool.question: What symptoms may result from other signals interfering with a PACTOR or WINMOR transmission?

answers.B: Long pauses in message transmission
answers.C: Failure to establish a connection between stations

question_pool.question: What segment of the 20-meter band is most often used for digital transmissions (avoiding the DX propagation beacons)?
What is the standard sideband used to generate a JT65, JT9, or FT8 digital signal when using AFSK in any amateur band?

answers.B: USB
answers.C: DSB

question_pool.question: What is the most common frequency shift for RTTY emissions in the amateur HF bands?

answers.B: 170 Hz
answers.C: 425 Hz

question_pool.question: What segment of the 80-meter band is most commonly used for digital transmissions?
In what segment of the 20-meter band are most PSK31 operations commonly found?

answers.A: At the bottom of the slow-scan TV segment, near 14.230 MHz
answers.B: At the top of the SSB phone segment, near 14.325 MHz
answers.C: In the middle of the CW segment, near 14.100 MHz
answers.D: Below the RTTY segment, near 14.070 MHz

question_pool.question: How do you join a contact between two stations using the PACTOR protocol?

answers.A: Send broadcast packets containing your call sign while in MONITOR mode
answers.B: Transmit a steady carrier until the PACTOR protocol times out and disconnects
answers.C: Joining an existing contact is not possible, PACTOR connections are limited to two stations
answers.D: Send a NAK response continuously so that the sending station must stand by

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a way to establish contact with a digital messaging system gateway station?

answers.A: Send an email to the system control operator
answers.B: Send QRL in Morse code
answers.C: Respond when the station broadcasts its SSID
answers.D: Transmit a connect message on the station’s published frequency

question_pool.question: Which of the following is characteristic of the FT8 mode of the WSJT-X family?

answers.A: It is a keyboard-to-keyboard chat mode
answers.B: Each transmission takes exactly 60 seconds
answers.C: It is limited to use on VHF
answers.D: Typical exchanges are limited to call signs, grid locators, and signal reports

question_pool.question: Which of the following connectors would be a good choice for a serial data port?

answers.B: Type N
answers.C: Type SMA

question_pool.question: Which communication system sometimes uses the internet to transfer messages?

answers.B: RTTY
answers.C: ARES

question_pool.question: What could be wrong if you cannot decode an RTTY or other FSK signal even though it is apparently tuned in properly?

answers.A: The mark and space frequencies may be reversed
answers.B: You may have selected the wrong baud rate
answers.C: You may be listening on the wrong sideband

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a requirement when using the FT8 digital mode?

answers.B: Computer time accurate within approximately 1 second
answers.C: Receiver attenuator set to -12 dB

question_pool.question: What is the significance of the sunspot number with regard to HF propagation?

answers.A: Higher sunspot numbers generally indicate a greater probability of good propagation at higher frequencies
answers.B: Lower sunspot numbers generally indicate greater probability of sporadic E propagation
answers.C: A zero sunspot number indicates that radio propagation is not possible on any band
answers.D: A zero sunspot number indicates undisturbed conditions

question_pool.question: What effect does a Sudden Ionospheric Disturbance have on the daytime ionospheric propagation of HF radio waves?

answers.A: It enhances propagation on all HF frequencies
answers.B: It disrupts signals on lower frequencies more than those on higher frequencies
answers.C: It disrupts communications via satellite more than direct communications
answers.D: None, because only areas on the night side of the Earth are affected

question_pool.question: Approximately how long does it take the increased ultraviolet and X-ray radiation from solar flares to affect radio propagation on Earth?

answers.B: 1 to 2 hours
answers.C: 8 minutes

question_pool.question: Which of the following are least reliable for long-distance communications during periods of low solar activity?

answers.B: 60 meters and 40 meters
answers.C: 30 meters and 20 meters

question_pool.question: What is the solar flux index?

answers.A: A measure of the highest frequency that is useful for ionospheric propagation between two points on Earth
answers.B: A count of sunspots that is adjusted for solar emissions
answers.C: Another name for the American sunspot number
answers.D: A measure of solar radiation at 10.7 centimeters wavelength

question_pool.question: What is a geomagnetic storm?

answers.A: A sudden drop in the solar flux index
answers.B: A thunderstorm that affects radio propagation
answers.C: Ripples in the ionosphere
answers.D: A temporary disturbance in Earth’s magnetosphere

question_pool.question: At what point in the solar cycle does the 20-meter band usually support worldwide propagation during daylight hours?

answers.B: Only at the maximum point of the solar cycle
answers.C: Only at the minimum point of the solar cycle
answers.D: At any point in the solar cycle

question_pool.question: Which of the following effects can a geomagnetic storm have on radio propagation?

answers.B: Degraded high-latitude HF propagation
answers.C: Improved ground wave propagation

question_pool.question: What benefit can high geomagnetic activity have on radio communications?

answers.A: Auroras that can reflect VHF signals
answers.B: Higher signal strength for HF signals passing through the polar regions
answers.C: Improved HF long path propagation

question_pool.question: What causes HF propagation conditions to vary periodically in a roughly 28-day cycle?

answers.A: Long term oscillations in the upper atmosphere
answers.B: Cyclic variation in Earth’s radiation belts
answers.C: The sun’s rotation on its axis
answers.D: The position of the moon in its orbit

question_pool.question: How long does it take charged particles from coronal mass ejections to affect radio propagation on Earth?

answers.B: 14 days
answers.C: 4 to 8 minutes

question_pool.question: What does the K-index indicate?

answers.A: The relative position of sunspots on the surface of the sun
answers.B: The short-term stability of Earth’s magnetic field
answers.C: The stability of the sun’s magnetic field
answers.D: The solar radio flux at Boulder, Colorado

question_pool.question: What does the A-index indicate?

answers.A: The relative position of sunspots on the surface of the sun
answers.B: The amount of polarization of the sun’s electric field
answers.C: The long-term stability of Earth’s geomagnetic field
answers.D: The solar radio flux at Boulder, Colorado

question_pool.question: How are radio communications usually affected by the charged particles that reach Earth from solar coronal holes?

answers.B: HF communications are disturbed
answers.C: VHF/UHF ducting is improved

question_pool.question: What is a characteristic of skywave signals arriving at your location by both short-path and long-path propagation?

answers.B: Signal strength increased by 3 dB
answers.C: The signal might be cancelled causing severe attenuation
answers.D: A slightly delayed echo might be heard

question_pool.question: What factors affect the MUF?

answers.B: Time of day and season
answers.C: Solar radiation and ionospheric disturbances

question_pool.question: Which of the following applies when selecting a frequency for lowest attenuation when transmitting on HF?

answers.A: Select a frequency just below the MUF
answers.B: Select a frequency just above the LUF
answers.C: Select a frequency just below the critical frequency
answers.D: Select a frequency just above the critical frequency

question_pool.question: What is a reliable way to determine if the MUF is high enough to support skip propagation between your station and a distant location on frequencies between 14 and 30 MHz?

answers.A: Listen for signals from an international beacon in the frequency range you plan to use
answers.B: Send a series of dots on the band and listen for echoes from your signal
answers.C: Check the strength of TV signals from western Europe
answers.D: Check the strength of signals in the MF AM broadcast band

question_pool.question: What usually happens to radio waves with frequencies below the MUF and above the LUF when they are sent into the ionosphere?

answers.A: They are bent back to Earth
answers.B: They pass through the ionosphere
answers.C: They are amplified by interaction with the ionosphere
answers.D: They are bent and trapped in the ionosphere to circle Earth

question_pool.question: What usually happens to radio waves with frequencies below the LUF?

answers.A: They are bent back to Earth
answers.B: They pass through the ionosphere
answers.C: They are completely absorbed by the ionosphere
answers.D: They are bent and trapped in the ionosphere to circle Earth

question_pool.question: What does LUF stand for?

answers.A: The Lowest Usable Frequency for communications between two points
answers.B: The Longest Universal Function for communications between two points
answers.C: The Lowest Usable Frequency during a 24-hour period
answers.D: The Longest Universal Function during a 24-hour period

question_pool.question: What does MUF stand for?

answers.A: The Minimum Usable Frequency for communications between two points
answers.B: The Maximum Usable Frequency for communications between two points
answers.C: The Minimum Usable Frequency during a 24-hour period
answers.D: The Maximum Usable Frequency during a 24-hour period

question_pool.question: What is the approximate maximum distance along the Earth’s surface that is normally covered in one hop using the F2 region?

answers.B: 1,200 miles
answers.C: 2,500 miles

question_pool.question: What is the approximate maximum distance along the Earth’s surface that is normally covered in one hop using the E region?

answers.B: 1,200 miles
answers.C: 2,500 miles

question_pool.question: What happens to HF propagation when the LUF exceeds the MUF?

answers.A: No HF radio frequency will support ordinary skywave communications over the path
answers.B: HF communications over the path are enhanced
answers.C: Double hop propagation along the path is more common
answers.D: Propagation over the path on all HF frequencies is enhanced

question_pool.question: Which ionospheric layer is closest to the surface of Earth?

answers.B: The E layer
answers.C: The F1 layer

question_pool.question: Where on Earth do ionospheric layers reach their maximum height?

answers.B: Where the sun is on the opposite side of Earth
answers.C: Where the sun is rising
answers.D: Where the sun has just set

question_pool.question: Why is the F2 region mainly responsible for the longest distance radio wave propagation?

answers.A: Because it is the densest ionospheric layer
answers.B: Because of the Doppler effect
answers.C: Because it is the highest ionospheric region
answers.D: Because of meteor trails at that level

question_pool.question: What does the term “critical angle” mean, as used in radio wave propagation?

answers.A: The long path azimuth of a distant station
answers.B: The short path azimuth of a distant station
answers.C: The lowest takeoff angle that will return a radio wave to Earth under specific ionospheric conditions
answers.D: The highest takeoff angle that will return a radio wave to Earth under specific ionospheric conditions

question_pool.question: Why is long-distance communication on the 40-meter, 60-meter, 80-meter, and 160-meter bands more difficult during the day?

answers.A: The F layer absorbs signals at these frequencies during daylight hours
answers.B: The F layer is unstable during daylight hours
answers.C: The D layer absorbs signals at these frequencies during daylight hours
answers.D: The E layer is unstable during daylight hours

question_pool.question: What is a characteristic of HF scatter?

answers.B: Signals have a fluttering sound
answers.C: There are very large, sudden swings in signal strength
answers.D: Scatter propagation occurs only at night

question_pool.question: What makes HF scatter signals often sound distorted?

answers.A: The ionospheric layer involved is unstable
answers.B: Ground waves are absorbing much of the signal
answers.C: The E-region is not present
answers.D: Energy is scattered into the skip zone through several different radio wave paths

question_pool.question: Why are HF scatter signals in the skip zone usually weak?

answers.A: Only a small part of the signal energy is scattered into the skip zone
answers.B: Signals are scattered from the magnetosphere, which is not a good reflector
answers.C: Propagation is through ground waves, which absorb most of the signal energy
answers.D: Propagation is through ducts in the F region, which absorb most of the energy

question_pool.question: What type of propagation allows signals to be heard in the transmitting station’s skip zone?

answers.B: Scatter
answers.C: Chordal hop

question_pool.question: What is Near Vertical Incidence Skywave (NVIS) propagation?

answers.B: Short distance MF or HF propagation using high elevation angles
answers.C: Long path HF propagation at sunrise and sunset
answers.D: Double hop propagation near the LUF

question_pool.question: Which ionospheric layer is the most absorbent of long skip signals during daylight hours on frequencies below 10 MHz?

answers.B: The F1 layer
answers.C: The E layer

question_pool.question: What is the purpose of the “notch filter” found on many HF transceivers?

answers.A: To restrict the transmitter voice bandwidth
answers.B: To reduce interference from carriers in the receiver passband
answers.C: To eliminate receiver interference from impulse noise sources
answers.D: To enhance the reception of a specific frequency on a crowded band

question_pool.question: What is one advantage of selecting the opposite, or “reverse,” sideband when receiving CW signals on a typical HF transceiver?

answers.A: Interference from impulse noise will be eliminated
answers.B: More stations can be accommodated within a given signal passband
answers.C: It may be possible to reduce or eliminate interference from other signals
answers.D: Accidental out-of-band operation can be prevented

question_pool.question: What is normally meant by operating a transceiver in “split” mode?

answers.A: The radio is operating at half power
answers.B: The transceiver is operating from an external power source
answers.C: The transceiver is set to different transmit and receive frequencies
answers.D: The transmitter is emitting an SSB signal, as opposed to DSB operation

question_pool.question: What reading on the plate current meter of a vacuum tube RF power amplifier indicates correct adjustment of the plate tuning control?

answers.B: A pronounced dip
answers.C: No change will be observed

question_pool.question: What is a reason to use Automatic Level Control (ALC) with an RF power amplifier?

answers.A: To balance the transmitter audio frequency response
answers.B: To reduce harmonic radiation
answers.C: To reduce distortion due to excessive drive

question_pool.question: What type of device is often used to match transmitter output impedance to an impedance not equal to 50 ohms?

answers.B: SWR bridge
answers.C: Antenna coupler or antenna tuner

question_pool.question: What condition can lead to permanent damage to a solid-state RF power amplifier?

answers.B: Low input SWR
answers.C: Shorting the input signal to ground

question_pool.question: What is the correct adjustment for the load or coupling control of a vacuum tube RF power amplifier?

answers.B: Minimum plate current without exceeding maximum allowable grid current
answers.C: Highest plate voltage while minimizing grid current
answers.D: Maximum power output without exceeding maximum allowable plate current

question_pool.question: Why is a time delay sometimes included in a transmitter keying circuit?

answers.A: To prevent stations from interfering with one another
answers.B: To allow the transmitter power regulators to charge properly
answers.C: To allow time for transmit-receive changeover operations to complete properly before RF output is allowed
answers.D: To allow time for a warning signal to be sent to other stations

question_pool.question: What is the purpose of an electronic keyer?

answers.B: Automatic generation of strings of dots and dashes for CW operation
answers.C: VOX operation
answers.D: Computer interface for PSK and RTTY operation

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a use for the IF shift control on a receiver?

answers.A: To avoid interference from stations very close to the receive frequency
answers.B: To change frequency rapidly
answers.C: To permit listening on a different frequency from that on which you are transmitting
answers.D: To tune in stations that are slightly off frequency without changing your transmit frequency

question_pool.question: Which of the following is a common use for the dual-VFO feature on a transceiver?

answers.A: To allow transmitting on two frequencies at once
answers.B: To permit full duplex operation — that is, transmitting and receiving at the same time
answers.C: To permit monitoring of two different frequencies

question_pool.question: What is one reason to use the attenuator function that is present on many HF transceivers?

answers.A: To reduce signal overload due to strong incoming signals
answers.B: To reduce the transmitter power when driving a linear amplifier
answers.C: To reduce power consumption when operating from batteries
answers.D: To slow down received CW signals for better copy

question_pool.question: What is likely to happen if a transceiver’s ALC system is not set properly when transmitting AFSK signals with the radio using single sideband mode?

answers.A: ALC will invert the modulation of the AFSK mode
answers.B: Improper action of ALC distorts the signal and can cause spurious emissions
answers.C: When using digital modes, too much ALC activity can cause the transmitter to overheat

question_pool.question: Which of the following can be a symptom of transmitted RF being picked up by an audio cable carrying AFSK data signals between a computer and a transceiver?

answers.A: The VOX circuit does not un-key the transmitter
answers.B: The transmitter signal is distorted
answers.C: Frequent connection timeouts

question_pool.question: How does a noise blanker work?

answers.B: By redirecting noise pulses into a filter capacitor
answers.C: By reducing receiver gain during a noise pulse

question_pool.question: What happens as the noise reduction control level in a receiver is increased?

answers.B: Received frequency may become unstable
answers.C: CW signals may become severely attenuated
answers.D: Received frequency may shift several kHz

question_pool.question: What item of test equipment contains horizontal and vertical channel amplifiers?

answers.B: A signal generator
answers.C: An ammeter

question_pool.question: Which of the following is an advantage of an oscilloscope versus a digital voltmeter?

answers.B: Complex impedances can be easily measured
answers.C: Input impedance is much lower

question_pool.question: Which of the following is the best instrument to use when checking the keying waveform of a CW transmitter?

answers.B: A field strength meter
answers.C: A sidetone monitor

question_pool.question: What signal source is connected to the vertical input of an oscilloscope when checking the RF envelope pattern of a transmitted signal?

answers.A: The local oscillator of the transmitter
answers.B: An external RF oscillator
answers.C: The transmitter balanced mixer output
answers.D: The attenuated RF output of the transmitter

question_pool.question: Why is high input impedance desirable for a voltmeter?

answers.B: It decreases battery consumption in the meter
answers.C: It improves the resolution of the readings
answers.D: It decreases the loading on circuits being measured

question_pool.question: What is an advantage of a digital voltmeter as compared to an analog voltmeter?

answers.B: Better for RF measurements
answers.C: Better precision for most uses

question_pool.question: What signals are used to conduct a two-tone test?

answers.A: Two audio signals of the same frequency shifted 90 degrees
answers.B: Two non-harmonically related audio signals
answers.C: Two swept frequency tones
answers.D: Two audio frequency range square wave signals of equal amplitude

question_pool.question: Which of the following instruments may be used to monitor relative RF output when making antenna and transmitter adjustments?

answers.B: An antenna noise bridge
answers.C: A multimeter

question_pool.question: Which of the following can be determined with a field strength meter?

answers.A: The radiation resistance of an antenna
answers.B: The radiation pattern of an antenna
answers.C: The presence and amount of phase distortion of a transmitter
answers.D: The presence and amount of amplitude distortion of a transmitter

question_pool.question: Which of the following can be determined with a directional wattmeter?

answers.B: Antenna front-to-back ratio
answers.C: RF interference

question_pool.question: Which of the following must be connected to an antenna analyzer when it is being used for SWR measurements?

answers.B: Transmitter
answers.C: Antenna and feed line

question_pool.question: What problem can occur when making measurements on an antenna system with an antenna analyzer?

answers.A: Permanent damage to the analyzer may occur if it is operated into a high SWR
answers.B: Strong signals from nearby transmitters can affect the accuracy of measurements
answers.C: The analyzer can be damaged if measurements outside the ham bands are attempted
answers.D: Connecting the analyzer to an antenna can cause it to absorb harmonics

question_pool.question: What is a use for an antenna analyzer other than measuring the SWR of an antenna system?

answers.A: Measuring the front-to-back ratio of an antenna
answers.B: Measuring the turns ratio of a power transformer
answers.C: Determining the impedance of coaxial cable
answers.D: Determining the gain of a directional antenna

question_pool.question: What is an instance in which the use of an instrument with analog readout may be preferred over an instrument with digital readout?

answers.B: When high precision is desired
answers.C: When measuring the frequency of an oscillator

question_pool.question: What type of transmitter performance does a two-tone test analyze?

answers.B: Percentage of suppression of carrier and undesired sideband for SSB
answers.C: Percentage of frequency modulation

question_pool.question: Which of the following might be useful in reducing RF interference to audio frequency devices?

answers.B: Bypass capacitor
answers.C: Forward-biased diode

question_pool.question: Which of the following could be a cause of interference covering a wide range of frequencies?

answers.A: Not using a balun or line isolator to feed balanced antennas
answers.B: Lack of rectification of the transmitter’s signal in power conductors
answers.C: Arcing at a poor electrical connection
answers.D: Using a balun to feed an unbalanced antenna

question_pool.question: What sound is heard from an audio device or telephone if there is interference from a nearby single sideband phone transmitter?

answers.A: A steady hum whenever the transmitter is on the air
answers.B: On-and-off humming or clicking
answers.C: Distorted speech

question_pool.question: What is the effect on an audio device when there is interference from a nearby CW transmitter?

answers.B: A CW signal at a nearly pure audio frequency
answers.C: A chirpy CW signal

question_pool.question: What might be the problem if you receive an RF burn when touching your equipment while transmitting on an HF band, assuming the equipment is connected to a ground rod?

answers.A: Flat braid rather than round wire has been used for the ground wire
answers.B: Insulated wire has been used for the ground wire
answers.C: The ground rod is resonant
answers.D: The ground wire has high impedance on that frequency

question_pool.question: What effect can be caused by a resonant ground connection?

answers.B: Corrosion of the ground rod
answers.C: High RF voltages on the enclosures of station equipment

question_pool.question: Why should soldered joints not be used with the wires that connect the base of a tower to a system of ground rods?

answers.A: The resistance of solder is too high
answers.B: Solder flux will prevent a low conductivity connection
answers.C: Solder has too high a dielectric constant to provide adequate lightning protection
answers.D: A soldered joint will likely be destroyed by the heat of a lightning strike

question_pool.question: Which of the following would reduce RF interference caused by common-mode current on an audio cable?

answers.A: Placing a ferrite choke around the cable
answers.B: Adding series capacitors to the conductors
answers.C: Adding shunt inductors to the conductors
answers.D: Adding an additional insulating jacket to the cable

question_pool.question: How can a ground loop be avoided?

answers.A: Connect all ground conductors in series
answers.B: Connect the AC neutral conductor to the ground wire
answers.C: Avoid using lock washers and star washers when making ground connections
answers.D: Connect all ground conductors to a single point

question_pool.question: What could be a symptom of a ground loop somewhere in your station?

answers.A: You receive reports of “hum” on your station’s transmitted signal
answers.B: The SWR reading for one or more antennas is suddenly very high
answers.C: An item of station equipment starts to draw excessive amounts of current
answers.D: You receive reports of harmonic interference from your station

question_pool.question: What technique helps to minimize RF “hot spots” in an amateur station?

answers.A: Building all equipment in a metal enclosure
answers.B: Using surge suppressor power outlets
answers.C: Bonding all equipment enclosures together
answers.D: Low-pass filters on all feed lines

question_pool.question: Which of the following is an advantage of a receiver DSP IF filter as compared to an analog filter?

answers.A: A wide range of filter bandwidths and shapes can be created
answers.B: Fewer digital components are required
answers.C: Mixing products are greatly reduced
answers.D: The DSP filter is much more effective at VHF frequencies

question_pool.question: Why must the metal enclosure of every item of station equipment be grounded?

answers.A: It prevents a blown fuse in the event of an internal short circuit
answers.B: It prevents signal overload
answers.C: It ensures that the neutral wire is grounded
answers.D: It ensures that hazardous voltages cannot appear on the chassis
